awd_titl_txt: Spectroscopic photon localization microscopy for super-resolution molecular imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will establish an optimized imaging system that can achieve three dimensional imaging at 1-nm spatial resolution and will allow a comprehensive investigation of photophysical properties of DNA. This advance will allow the achievement of nanoscopic DNA imaging in living cells without extrinsic labeling under natural conditions. 
The PIs are actively involved in several excellent outreach programs, including the Boys and Girls Club of Chicago, the Young Leadership Charter School, and the Poster Fair to promote local high school students to STEM programs?

An exciting new technology, spectroscopic photon localization microscopy (SPLM), was recently discovered by the PI and Co-PI where native DNA fluoresces and blinks under low level visible light excitation. This technology overcomes the limitations in traditional super-resolution microscopy technologies and opens new opportunities for studying biological macromolecules (such as proteins and DNA) without the need for labeling in a live cell environment. The potential for scientific discovery is significant and the impact broad.

por.por_cntn:
There is a need for nanoscopic imaging techniques to visualize interactions of multiple biomolecules. Very little happens in biological processes until two or more biomolecules (e.g., proteins, DNAs) come together and interact at the nanoscale. One major existing scientific challenge is to reveal these biomolecular assemblies, their functions, and their interactions in structurally and dynamically complex cellular systems. Understanding nanoscale structure-function relationships and biological processes in the context of highly complex nanoscopic environments will open up the next frontier for biological discovery. For instance, molecular trafficking between the nucleus and cytoplasm is accomplished through cylindrical macromolecular channels termed nuclear pore complex (NPC). Increasing evidence suggests that NPC is the central unit with multiple functions along the gene expression ?path? other than the only role of nucleoplasmic transport. On the nucleoplasmic side, the NPC interacts with nuclear periphery to regulate gene expression at transcriptional and epigenetic levels. On the cytoplasmic side, the filaments that extend from the NPC connect to the protein synthesis machinery and ensure correct cargo transportation and information transfer. Nonetheless, the spatial organization of these complex biomolecular interactions remains poorly understood because the unambiguous visualization of these nanoscale events is obscured by the optical diffraction limit.

Single-molecule localization microscopy (SMLM) provides multi-color imaging capability at the nanoscale. SMLM techniques, such as stochastic optical reconstruction microscopy, photo-activated localization microscopy, and point accumulation for imaging nanoscale topography, offer the visualization of biomolecules with spatial resolutions beyond the optical diffraction limit (down to 10 nm). In SMLM, the spatial resolution is fundamentally constrained by the photon budget of fluorophores, reaching around 10-20 nm in cellular imaging. However, current SMLM technologies are unable to image highly multiplexed molecular interactions, which is limited by the bandwidths (>100 nm) of fluorophores? emission spectra and separating emission spectra using dichroic mirrors. As a result, current multiple color SMLM is mostly limited to 2 to 3 moecular contrast.

This NSF award enabled us to develop, optimize, and test several technical implementations of a new SMLM, referred to as spectroscopic SMLM or sSMLM, for highly-multiplexed super-resolution for the first time. In sSMLM we divide the emitted photons from individual molecules into spatial and spectral channels using either a single dispersive component (such as optical grating) or an optical assembly (containing beam splitters and optical prisms). Then we simultaneously capture images in spatial and spectral channels and use the images for localizing the spatial positions and analyzing the full emission spectra of individual single-molecule blinking events, respectively. As a result, the number of distinguishable fluorescent labels is, in principle, unlimited as sSMLM analyzes the full spectra of all labels, even if they have highly overlapped spectra. Currently, sSMLM can simultaneously distinguish up to four molecular labels whose emission peaks are about 10 nm apart and achieve subcellular imaging within a few to tens of minutes. Meanwhile, we have conducted thorough theoretical investigations to understand the detection limit in sSMLM and designed a compact optical assembly with minimal photon loss. The latest sSMLM technology implementation uses a dual-wedge prism assembly and can be easily integrated with any existing SMLM system to achieve spectroscopic super-resolution imaging. We welcome interested researchers to contact us to adopt sSMLM in various biological studies.
